awd_titl_txt: Programs at the Fields Institute for Research in Mathematical Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the participation of U.S.-based mathematical scientists in scientific activities held at the Fields Institute for Research in Mathematical Sciences. The direct impact of NSF funding consists of contributing to the training of a considerable number of junior U.S. researchers (early-career faculty, postdoctoral fellows, and graduate students), who are given the opportunity to participate in activities at the Fields Institute. The primary activities of the Fields Institute -- Thematic and Focus Programs -- are extended periods of deep research concentration on topics of current research interest in the mathematical sciences. These range from one to six months in length and involve long- and short-term visitors, postdoctoral fellows, and students; the programs include workshops and seminars, distinguished lectures, and graduate courses. Program organizers strive to ensure strong participation by women, minorities, and other groups traditionally underrepresented in the mathematical sciences. The activities bring together world leaders, industrial partners, and researchers for sustained periods of communication and collaboration, leading to rapid progress on problems of great current significance, enhanced global research networks, and increased interdisciplinary research. 

This project supports the participation of U.S.-based mathematicians and statisticians in activities held at the Fields Institute for Research in Mathematical Sciences.  Funded programs are assured to be of the highest caliber, as rated by the Institute's Scientific Advisory Panel. The Fields Institute's means of dissemination, including publications, website, live online webcasting, and video archiving, contribute towards wide communication of the scientific results arising from the activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Fields Institute for Research in Mathematical Sciences hosted 518 mathematicians and researchers based in the United States to participate in 55 events at the Institute, or to hold positions as postdoctoral fellows. A large amount of support was directed to attendees in the early stages of their academic career (e.g. Graduate students, early career faculty and postdoctoral fellows) with an effort to also include groups traditionally underrepresented in mathematics, including women and visible minorities.

The types of events that included NSF-funded participants included long-term Thematic and Focus programs, which take place over a month or longer, as well as shorter workshops and conferences. There are also seminars, courses and summer schools on a full range of subjects related to mathematics. With the difficulties in cross-border traffic caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, Fields asked and received permission to redirect NSF funds to support long-term postdoctoral fellows instead of travel expenses, therefore minimizing the need to travel back and forth over the border. During the first months of the pandemic, postdocs could remain in the United States and engage with Fields activities remotely.

With this redirection of funds, the number of US-based researchers impacted by this grant reduced, but the critical support of postdoctoral fellows allowed for deep, long term engagement. So, rather than 100-200 US based researchers receiving travel support to attend a week-long workshop, 5-6 Postdoctoral Fellows received support to stay at Fields for 6 months or longer. Speaking in the Spring 2023 edition of Fields Notes, Dr. Therese Landry illuminates the importance of her time as a Fields Postdoctoral Fellow:

Being a postdoc at Fields gave me the time, space and resources to develop new research directions and contacts. In my last month at the Institute, I submitted a paper resulting from my first collaboration as a postdoc. It was recently accepted for publication in the Journal of Noncommutative Geometry.

Therese also represents another demographic supported by NSF funds ? those underrepresented in mathematics. "I felt a responsibility and privilege in being able to show members of underrepresented groups that someone like them with a non-traditional academic background can also be a Fields postdoc." - Dr. Therese Landry, Fields Notes, Spring 2023

Participants engaged with a global community of mathematicians in 15 different long-term Thematic and Focus programs on topics ranging from Mathematical Biology to Tame Geometry, Transseries and Applications to Analysis and Geometry. The attended 40 short-term workshops on a wide range of topics. During this period, more than 130 papers and books and 120 presentations have been reported as research outputs generated by specific events at Fields and at least one field of study became crucial during the pandemic. The Fields Institute led an initiative to use mathematical modelling to predict the spread of COVID-19.

Community building does not just happen in lectures and seminars. The long-term visiting postdoctoral fellows, in particular, engaged in social events and, in one case, was featured in a video about the 30th Anniversary of the Fields Institute (https://www.fields.utoronto.ca/special-videos/Fields-at-30.mp4). We include images of some of our visitors engaging in these events, including Therese Landry in her Koch Snowflake sweater and Alexi Block-Gorman filming her stand up for the Fields @ 30 video.

 In summary, through the challenges of 2020-2021, Fields was able to maintain a robust set of programs and to host many visiting mathematicians based in the United States to engage with those programs. From these a strong set of research outputs, some critical in the face of the pandemic, were produced. The Institute is eager to continue to grow the relationships it has forged with US-based researchers.
